questions.stem: Tetanus in horses is BEST described as:

options.label: A
options.text: A viral disease causing respiratory failure

options.label: B
options.text: A bacterial infection in necrotic tissue producing a neurotoxin that causes muscular spasms

options.label: C
options.text: A fungal infection limited to the skin

options.label: D
options.text: A protozoal infection of the GI tract

questions.explanation: Tetanus is a bacterial disease caused by *Clostridium tetani* in necrotic tissue, producing a neurotoxin that results in muscular spasms. It is not viral (A), fungal (C), or protozoal GI disease (D).

questions.stem: Horses are considered:

options.label: B
options.text: Among the most sensitive species to tetanus toxin

questions.explanation: Horses are among the most sensitive species to tetanus toxin, which is why vaccination and prompt wound care are so critical. They are neither resistant (A) nor unaffected (C), and risk is not limited to foals (D).

questions.stem: Clostridium tetani is BEST characterized as:

options.label: B
options.text: An anaerobic, Gram-positive, spore-forming bacillus with terminal spherical spores

questions.explanation: *C. tetani* is an anaerobic, Gram-positive, spore-forming bacillus with terminal spherical spores found in soil and feces. The other descriptions (A, C, D) fit different organisms.

questions.stem: How does C. tetani typically gain access to the horse’s body?

options.label: B
options.text: Entry through a contaminated wound where low oxygen tension allows germination

options.label: D
options.text: Oral ingestion and colonization of the stomach

questions.explanation: The organism gains access via contaminated wounds where low oxygen tension permits spore germination and toxin production. Inhalation (A), vertical transmission (C), and gastric colonization (D) are not typical routes.

questions.stem: Which condition at the wound site favors germination and proliferation of C. tetani?

options.label: B
options.text: Anaerobic environment due to necrosis, foreign material, or concurrent infection

questions.explanation: An anaerobic environment caused by necrosis, foreign material, or mixed infection favors germination and growth of *C. tetani* in the wound. Highly oxygenated (A), intact (C), or sun-exposed (D) sites are less conducive.

questions.stem: The main neurotoxin responsible for clinical tetanus signs is:
questions.explanation: Tetanospasmin is the main neurotoxin responsible for clinical signs; tetanolysin (A) contributes to local necrosis, while botulinum toxin (C) is from *C. botulinum*.

questions.stem: Tetanospasmin primarily acts by:

options.label: A
options.text: Blocking acetylcholine release at neuromuscular junctions

options.label: B
options.text: Cleaving synaptobrevin in presynaptic inhibitory interneurons, preventing release of glycine and GABA

options.label: C
options.text: Destroying myelin sheaths around motor axons

options.label: D
options.text: Increasing serotonin release in the CNS

questions.explanation: Tetanospasmin travels to the CNS and cleaves synaptobrevin in presynaptic inhibitory interneurons, blocking glycine and GABA release and disinhibiting motor neurons. Blocking acetylcholine (A) describes botulism, not tetanus.

questions.stem: The result of tetanospasmin action on the spinal cord is:

options.label: A
options.text: Enhanced inhibition of motor neurons and flaccid paralysis

options.label: B
options.text: Loss of motor neuron inhibition causing hypertonia and muscular spasm

questions.explanation: The loss of inhibitory input leads to hypertonia and generalized muscular spasms, producing the classic “stiff” horse. Flaccid paralysis (A), isolated sensory neuropathy (C), or demyelination (D) are not typical.

questions.stem: Which additional exotoxin produced by C. tetani increases local tissue necrosis?
questions.explanation: Tetanolysin promotes local tissue necrosis, furthering anaerobic conditions and bacterial proliferation. The other toxins (B–D) are produced by different bacteria.

questions.stem: The incubation period for tetanus in horses is usually:
questions.explanation: The incubation period is usually 1–3 weeks but can vary widely, consistent with spore germination and toxin spread. Hours (A), many months (C), or years (D) are incorrect.

questions.stem: Which horses are at highest risk for tetanus?

options.label: B
options.text: Unvaccinated horses with contaminated wounds or penetrating foot injuries

questions.explanation: Unvaccinated horses with contaminated soft tissue or penetrating foot wounds are at greatest risk, though vaccinated horses can rarely be affected. Horses with no wounds (C) or only foals with diarrhea (D) are not the main risk groups.

questions.stem: Early clinical signs of tetanus in a horse may include:

options.label: B
options.text: Local stiffness, lameness, colic, and progression to a stiff/spastic gait

questions.explanation: Early signs include history of a wound, local stiffness, lameness, colic-like discomfort, and progression to a stiff, spastic gait. Isolated ocular or respiratory signs (A, C) and pruritus (D) are not typical first signs.

questions.stem: Classic overt signs of tetanus include:

options.label: A
options.text: “Sawhorse stance,” raised tail head, flared nostrils, erect ears, third eyelid prolapse, and “lockjaw”

options.label: B
options.text: Hindlimb knuckling and toe dragging only

options.label: C
options.text: Severe ataxia with knuckling but no muscle tone change

questions.explanation: Classic overt signs include “sawhorse stance,” raised tail head, flared nostrils, erect ears, third eyelid prolapse, and lockjaw due to masseter spasm. The other answer choices (B–D) are incomplete or incorrect.

questions.stem: As tetanus progresses, which additional signs are commonly observed?

options.label: B
options.text: Dysphagia with saliva accumulation, aspiration risk, increased temperature, profuse sweating, recumbency, extensor rigidity, difficulty urinating/defecating, and respiratory failure

options.label: D
options.text: Purely GI colic with no neuromuscular signs

questions.explanation: Progressive tetanus causes dysphagia, saliva accumulation, aspiration risk, hyperthermia, profuse sweating, recumbency, severe extensor rigidity, difficulty urinating/defecating, and respiratory failure. Hypothermia (A), mild lethargy (C), and isolated colic (D) do not summarize advanced disease.

questions.stem: Which conditions are important DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSES for tetanus?

options.label: A
options.text: Laminitis, hypocalcemia, rhabdomyolysis, rabies, and myotonia

questions.explanation: Differential diagnoses include laminitis, hypocalcemia, rhabdomyolysis, rabies, and myotonia, which can mimic some neuromuscular aspects. Colic, navicular, and asthma (B–D) are less comparable.

questions.stem: What is the cornerstone of initial tetanus treatment in horses?

options.label: B
options.text: Neutralizing unbound toxin with tetanus antitoxin and eliminating infection at the wound, plus intensive nursing care

options.label: D
options.text: Immediate surgical amputation of the affected limb

questions.explanation: Initial treatment focuses on neutralizing unbound toxin with tetanus antitoxin, eliminating the infection via wound debridement and antimicrobials, and providing intensive nursing care. Steroids alone (A), antifungals (C), or limb amputation (D) are not appropriate primary strategies.

questions.stem: Which nursing measures are appropriate for a horse with tetanus?

options.label: A
options.text: Keeping the horse in a bright, noisy environment to maintain alertness

options.label: B
options.text: Confining to a quiet, dark stall with deep bedding, minimizing stimulation, using padded walls/helmet, and frequent turning of recumbent horses

options.label: C
options.text: Forcing the horse to exercise to prevent muscle stiffness

options.label: D
options.text: Withholding water to reduce aspiration risk

questions.explanation: Nursing care requires a quiet, dark environment, deep bedding, minimal stimulation, padded surroundings, and frequent repositioning or slinging of recumbent horses. Bright/noisy environments (A), forced exercise (C), and fluid restriction (D) increase risk.

questions.stem: Which antimicrobial is commonly used to treat C. tetani infection?
questions.explanation: Penicillin G IV (22,000–44,000 IU/kg q6h for 7–10 days) is a standard choice for killing vegetative *C. tetani*. Acyclovir (B), fluconazole (C), and praziquantel (D) target viruses, fungi, and parasites respectively.

questions.stem: Why must tetanus antitoxin (TAT) and tetanus toxoid be given at different injection sites?

options.label: A
options.text: To avoid local irritation at a single site

options.label: B
options.text: Because TAT can bind and neutralize the toxoid antigen if given at the same site

options.label: D
options.text: To improve vaccine absorption through multiple muscles

questions.explanation: TAT contains antibodies that can bind and neutralize tetanus toxoid antigen if both are injected at the same site, reducing vaccine effectiveness, so separate sites are recommended. Local irritation (A), hepatotoxicity (C), and “better absorption” (D) are not the main reasons.

questions.stem: Which statement BEST summarizes prognosis in equine tetanus?

options.label: B
options.text: Mortality is high (50–80%); recumbent horses unable to rise have grave prognosis, whereas horses that remain standing and receive excellent nursing care may recover over weeks

options.label: C
options.text: Tetanus is always fatal within 24 hours

options.label: D
options.text: Prognosis is excellent regardless of clinical severity

questions.explanation: Prognosis is guarded to poor, with reported mortality of 50–80%; recumbent horses unable to rise fare worst, while standing horses with good care can recover over weeks. It is neither uniformly benign (A, D) nor universally fatal within 24 hours (C).
